title: Huge software issue by Nintendo if this is your secondary console!!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on October 16, 2019
text: If you are purchasing this as your secondary Nintendo switch or share games between family members, you'll be very disappointed.Sharing digital games between multiple systems sucks. You can set one console as your primary, allowing you to play games anywhere without an internet connection. But to play digital titles on secondary systems, you'll have to be connected to the internet and it's also authenticated every three hours. Even worse, you can only play games through the account that originally purchased them. That's a problem for families where one parent account typically buys digital games.The Switch is meant to be portable. I ended up having to make it my primary system to play digital games on the go. But that also meant my original Switch was basically trapped on the dock under my TV. I was forced to restart progress on games that don't support the Switch Online's cloud saves.Family members wouldn't be able to play anything on the docked Switch on their own accounts. They'd be forced to play under my username, which could be a problem when it comes to managing saved games. And, worst of all, they wouldn't be able to play any of my digital games on that system offline.While multi-Switch households could swap around physical game carts, that introduces a whole new set of problems, especially with kids. Physical games can easily be lost or damaged, and you'll also have to be more mindful about trading games between systems. That's particularly true with the Switch, since each system might be traveling with a different person, instead of being set up throughout your home. Carts are also just annoying to plug in -- sure, that just takes a few seconds, but it's not nearly as seamless as booting up a digital game.The biggest problem with limiting yourself to carts? It's kind of impossible on the Switch, since it has a robust library of indie titles that are only available digitally. As much as I'd love to see a cart for Untitled Goose Game, it's not worth waiting around to see if one ever appears. Digital games are basically an inescapable problem for every Switch owner.

title: Only for a casual switch fan
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on May 31, 2020
text: While I may not have purchased this product, I have done my research on the system to get a valid point on this mini console. Starting off with the retail price of $200 is too much if you want to be able to enjoy the switch library. What I mean by this is that the switch light doesn‚Äôt have the detachable controllers (joycons) that many games NEED to be able to play. An example of this would be just dance or super Mario party. A pair of joycons is roughly $80 and then you have to buy a joycons charger for them because the lite can‚Äôt charge them so your looking at around $310. At that price you should have just spent the money on a regular switch that is superior to the lite in almost all ways. That being said, the switch lite is good for kids that want to play one or two games on a switch. If you wanted to fully dive into the switch library then I would suggest a regular switch because it is still portable and it can connect to the tv ( lite‚Äôs can‚Äôt do that) and it has better battery life. My final problem is about the joysticks on the switch lite and the regular switch‚Äôs joycons. After a while of use, the joysticks start to drift ( move without any input) witch can really damper someone‚Äôs experience with a game. Nintendo offers free repairs in certain parts of the US but if this happens with the lite ( it will happen eventually) you would have to send in the entire console just to get the joysticks fixed! Overall I feel like this console is good for people who want to play a few games on the switch that don‚Äôt care about seeing them on a tv.

title: Awesome console, awful, draconian DRM
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on March 3, 2020
text: Getting this as your only switch? Have fun - it's cute, it's light, it's absolutely fine. Most/all of your games are physical? Enjoy!Getting this as a second Switch? Unless you're going on a purely physical games route DON'T DO IT. I can't stress this enough. Honestly, I thought the naysayers are over-exaggerating and it couldn't be that bad, right? Wrong. It's much worse than expected:The DRM is quite draconian and requires an Internet check for every single E-Shop game, and a constant connection throughout your gaming session. Worse still, I have multiple accounts which I buy from, so I'm forced to try and remember the exact account which I bought the specific game from otherwise the game won't even start. The process goes like that:"Hmm, I feel like a bit Binding of Isaac this evening. Where did I put the Lite? Ah, here it is. Connect it, run the game, the check takes a few seconds...nope, that's not the account that bought it. Was it that account?....Still nope. I could have sworn it was on this account! No? Damn it, which account was it?!" If this was just a few games it wouldn't be that big of an issue. I have about 60 digital games spread over 8 different accounts downloaded to 1TB SD Card. I hope you see the problem here.But do you think that's end of it? It goes even lower than that: I sometimes bought games on one account, and their DLC on another. This means that I can't play these games with their respective DLC's unless I buy either the game or its DLC's again on one, specific account. The Lite feels like an expensive brick now.This is a shameful, completely customer unfriendly attitude by Nintendo, and no amount of apologetic brown-nosing fan service will change that. We're being treated like thieves for legitimately buying digital games. I'm being forced to purchase physical from now on if I want to play properly, but I'm having a hard time even justifying buying more games at this point.You have been warned.

title: Dreaded joy con drift!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on February 19, 2020
text: This switch lite was purchased from Amazon as a Christmas gift.  It wasn't put into use until mid January.  About a week ago the joy stick started to malfunction.  It's intermittent, sometimes starting right away, sometimes not starting till you're playing about 20 minutes. Sometimes it's not too bad,  and sometimes you can't even control the character which is horrible. Called Nintendo couple of days ago and the man emailed me a return label.  They are not even fixing the joycons on the original switch, just sending replacements.  He did say that because it's a switch lite they would try to fix it, but they might have to replace it.  It's the Pokemon special edition version and he said they would NOT be able to replace it with that version.  That's the first issue.  Another issue is that it has 2 large unfinished game saves, Links Awakening and Pokemon Sword. They're saved on the internal memory of the hardware (why oh why can't we save on an sd card,  Nintendo.  Oh that's right we're supposed to buy cloud service for saved games,  but wait,  Pokemon can't be saved on Nintendo online service)  so if they have to send a replacement machine what happens to all the saved data? He said they would certainly try to port the data to the replacement switch,  but he really didn't make any promises. Great.  So now what to do?  Maybe forget sending it back and just buy a different controller. That certainly makes the lite less portable.  And shouldn't your hardware just work? I would really like Nintendo to solve this problem but I'm very concerned about sending it back to them. The switch lite seems like a great idea but because of this joycon problem I cannot recommend it at all.  If you do buy it, put it thru it's paces right away so you can return it if yours develops the issue.  But who's to say this problem wouldn't happen as soon as your return window closes.

title: Good price on a mobile game system
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2020
text: I love this system but I gave it four stars because I cannot play any of my downloaded games away from home and also the battery life could definitely be better than a couple of hours! Other than that be prepared to bring all physical games with you that you want to play while on the go because without internet that‚Äôs all you‚Äôll be able to do! Great system for kids who can read though as long as they take care of their things and don‚Äôt lose every game you buy them or the charger to the system! I definitely recommend this system because you can pretty much play every game made but only a few that require the motion feature and detachable joy cons that only the regular switch can do! Good enough for me minus the small complaints mentioned above! I really wish they‚Äôd fix the not being able to play downloaded games without internet on the go because it really can limit you! I have 18 downloaded games

title: I'm Loving It!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on January 2, 2023
text: This was my first hand held "gaming device," and I absolutely love it. I had a Wii growing up, so I was so looking forward to the nostolgia of playing Mario Kart! It shipped fast and came very secure. I was able to turn it on, create an account, and start playing right away. I really like how portable and durable the nintendo switch lite is. For someone who just wants to play Mario Kart and Animal Crossing, it was perfect for me. I would recommend purchasing a MicroSD card right away, as the device does not have a lot of storage and was filled after downloading a few games. Nintendo Switch games are expensive, but I have very much enjoyed all of them!

title: Happy with my purchase!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on September 15, 2022
text: My boyfriend bought me a switch! I had no problem with it but you should know a few things before buying. If you‚Äôre buying the switch to play with friends or your partner (which is what I did), you have to pay for online. Which is not that bad, I paid $8 for 3 months. You also don‚Äôt have to go out of your way to buy the games before receiving it (which is what I did lol). There‚Äôs an E-store where you can buy every single game. I prefer that option so you don‚Äôt have to look and worry to see if it‚Äôs compatible with switch lite. They also got free games if you can afford none. The only down side is that it did took a while to download. By the time I got out the shower, only one game downloaded. The audio kinda sucks ngl. I‚Äôm playing minecraft and (full volume) I could barely hear the music, and I love peaceful minecraft music so that sucks. Also get ready to sign in to every game you have!This other part is about Amazon,When I bought it, the next day Amazon refunded my money and canceled the order which was very weird but I didn‚Äôt say much about it. Two days later they took the money again. The delivery took forever! By the time it was delivered to the lockers, it was 8pm. I still got my items so it doesn‚Äôt matter.

title: For The Kid Inside of You
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2020
text: As a disclaimer, I did not buy this from Amazon. Please do not pay more than the retail price of 199.99. I am a 41-year-old woman and I have a soft spot for Nintendo games, Mario, Zelda, Fire Emblem, etc. I did not get a regular Switch. I just got this, I did not want to hook this up to my TV, and I play solo anyway so I did not see the point of spending an extra $100 dollars. Some games are better played with a controller than on the unit itself. I love the color, it's more of a green than a blue. I suggest you get a case for it as well, I bought the official switch lite carry case from Nintendo. Also if you don't want to play the unit laying flat you can get a playing stand. See the pictures above for the accessories that I purchased.  My only complaints are that the charger is too big and also there is not enough internal storage, you need to get a micro SD card, I suggest a minimum of 128gb since some games are getting harder to find and some are download only. I'm more of a casual player as for families if you have children and if they don't mind sharing this could work or if you just have one child, if not than the regular switch might be better. This system is really fun to play with.

title: Great system, Downloadable Content Works Fine without WiFi
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on May 29, 2021
text: Someone on here said that you can‚Äôt use downloadable games on the Switch lite without the internet. This same person seemed pretty upset, using hyperbole and all caps. Except what they said is not true. In fact, you just set your switch lite to be your primary system, and the regular Switch can be the one that checks to make sure about said digital content. Nintendo is protecting themselves again possible misuse and piracy. I have this setup for myself, and I don‚Äôt have to think twice. Keep in mind Nintendo is constantly updating the Switch OS, so if they can change it without compromising their IP rights, I‚Äôm sure they will.I love my Switch lite, but it‚Äôs not for everyone. Most people will want one mainly as a second system. For portable use only. And it‚Äôs one of the most comfortable, affordable portable gaming systems Nintendo has ever made. No gimmicks, just great design, and a good price ($179.99 seems like a better price point. Or have a pack in game). Can‚Äôt wait to play Metroid Prime 4 and Breath of the Wild 2 on my lite later this year.

I don't know if there is an issue with my console itself, but I feel I wasted a good amount of money with this.
